intro: Cytinus hypocistis subsp. clusii, commonly known as the "broad-lobed broomrape," is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Orobanchaceae family. It is characterized by its lack of chlorophyll and reliance on host plants for nutrients, typically growing on the roots of legumes. The plant produces showy, yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its fleshy, inflated fruit is distinctive and contains numerous small seeds. Native to the Mediterranean region, it is often found in rocky or arid environments.
